Posts.Content: May 24, 2009 09:18AM Kaidog wrote: Jeannette, Biopsies are pretty painless during and afterwards. Less painful than the dentist giving you a filling! You might need a couple of Tylenol afterwards, but that's it.   Keep us posted - we're all praying that you've got nothing more than a very happy fibroadenoma in your breast... pretty common in women your age.  I had a nice-sized cyst when I was a few years older than you and it scared the heck out of me.    Love, Laura
Posts.Title: Too Young I need advice. netty90 Kaidog

Posts.Content: May 25, 2009 07:14AM Kaidog wrote: Jeanette, tell your radiologist that you want the biopsy and the results ASAP from the pathologist because of your finals.  Don't be afraid to ask for special treatment - you are quite young and I bet they'll give it to you!  Your parents can help you advocate for yourself, too.  I know it's hard but try not to fret.  I'm no MD, but I do know that juvenile fibroadenomas can grow really fast, honey, and they're common in women between 18 and 35 years of age - far, far more common than breast cancer!  It's a hormone thing. I'm saying prayers that you're one of those women prone to fibroadenomas and lumpy breasts.... Let us know what happens, okay?  We're here for you in all outcomes.  Love, Laura
Posts.Title: Too Young I need advice. netty90 Kaidog

Posts.Content: Kaidog wrote: Hey ladies, I'm 40 years old and had a bilateral MX with reconstruction 6 days ago.  The pain is fine, but the exhaustion is what's getting me. I quit taking the vicodin except before I go to bed, but even during the day on just Tylenol, I'm soooo tired!   I can move around for a couple of hours doing light stuff - a few dishes, putting away laundry, tossing dog toys - and then I'm ready for a 2 hour nap.  I'm wondering if I'm just being a big baby, or if feeling this sleepy all the time after surgery is typical.  Does this sound familiar?  How long does this last?    Thanks!!  Trying to love my chemo curls Dx 4/10/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/4 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Exhaustion Kaidog lumineaux

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2009 03:10PM Kaidog wrote: Hi footprints, I hope you're doing well, too.  I hear that chemo can knock you flat.   My update...  For those of you who've just had an MX and are wondering when you'll stop feeling like lying in bed all day long with the blanket over your head, my post-surgery exhaustion went away about 8 days after surgery.  I'd feel normal in the morning, need a couple of hours' nap about 1PM, and then be fine through bedtime. The need to nap went away over the course of the next couple of weeks.  Now I'm normal... back to work... but when sitting at my desk I think longingly of my afternoon naps! Laura
Posts.Title: Exhaustion Kaidog lumineaux

Posts.Content: May 7, 2009 01:33AM Kaidog wrote: After posting this message I went back to bed and slept 2 hours...  I am NOT used to being like this, so tired all the time!  The worst thing is not feeling like doing anything at all except reading and sleeping... I'm used to being much more self disciplined, but I just want to avoid everything and hide in bed and hope the world disappears.   I go in for a checkup Friday, which marks the first week after my surgery. I'll ask my surgeon then what to expect in terms of exhaustion and recovery.  From what y'all are telling me, I'll be tired for a couple more weeks. Deb, I'm glad you've got a mother in law who's willing to pitch in... :)  L.
Posts.Title: Exhaustion Kaidog lumineaux

Posts.Content: May 9, 2009 10:29PM Kaidog wrote: Hey ladies!  I'm actually feeling a lot better 9 days after surgery... I have more energy, but I'm still taking a nap every day and spending more time reading than I have in years!  It's nice.   My husband is GREAT with housework; I do it because I am bored and can't stand not moving around. Sounds like you all know what I'm talking about...  Anyway, hope you're all doing great.  Laura

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 07:26AM Kaidog wrote: Hey Susie in New Zealand, and everyone everywhere else!  I'm just about recovered from surgery and ready to start (and finish) the 'Second Act of Laura's Cancer Treatment.'  I'll be getting my teeth cleaned Thursday, my port will be "installed" a week from Tuesday and I'll be starting the TCH cocktails sometime after that.   Yesterday I cut off most of my hair and donated it to Locks of Love.  I actually really LIKE my hair shorter, which was a surprise.   I'm going to do the scarf and hat thing, mostly; but I'll probably order a wig today just in case... Cheers,  Laura
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2009 11:05AM Kaidog wrote: Hey MamaQ, I am WITH you on the Neulasta thing - I'm praying that I won't have to do it myself.  Since I'm on the 3-week TCH cycle, my oncologist thinks that my body will have time to regenerate my WBC - it worked last time, hopefully will work this time too.   I am sorry about the stories you're hearing about cancer deaths - they're all so sad.  Just remember that your story is your own, and that most women with BC do really well long term.  Tammy, you crack me up.  I quit caring about people staring at me real fast.  It's just too hot.  Albuquerque's not full of tourists this time of year and I'm always running into people I know, but, oh well.   I just don't care anymore.    By the way, my oncology center has a nutritionist who came to talk to me while I was in the chemo chair, drugged to all get-out on atavan and benadryl.  All I remember is, "Protein."  I'm sure I was slurring my speech...
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2009 08:33AM Kaidog wrote: Hey ladies, Candy and Cherneski, I love your photos!   I should have mohawked when I had the chance. I am getting SO bald.  I just did my second round of TCH on the 29th and wow...  is my hair falling out!  I am using duct tape to get the little fuzzies off.  I just want to be completely bald so that I don't look like a mangy cur.  I don't mind being nice, clean, tidy bald - but I hate being patchy bald.  Gjlanders, so glad you're having a great time - it's neat to see travel posts on this board, reminds me that life is full of wonderful things that are definitely worth fighting for! Hugs, Laura
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2009 06:36AM Kaidog wrote: PDaw, I got a waterpik and use it to get stuff from between my teeth.  I use salt water with baking soda and it really helps with the mouth sores and keeps my gumshealthy.  Bettina, I am DYING laughing at your story.  That is hilarious.  I bet she feels like an idiot, but that's a good lesson for her.    My hair started coming out in handfuls on Tuesday so I buzzed it.  My mom brought me a bunch of scarves and the hairdresser showed me how to tie a turban.  All well and fine, except that when I got to work the next day, I suddenly decided, "Aw, screw it, it's hot."  So I went bareheaded.... You know those dreams where you're walking around in a public place naked and wondering if anyone's noticed?  That's kind of how I felt.  But it was also kind of nice, in a weird way, because I felt like this was as bad as the transformation was going to get.     It won't get more embarassing than this... and it wasn't very embarassing, actually.  My coworkers are incredibly enlightened and that makes it a lot easier.  Also, they all know what's going on - I told everyone when I got diagnosed.  Bettina I'm happy to report that no one tried to touch my head!   We had a thunderstorm last night and it was cool and smelled so good, and I took the dogs to walk around, and the air felt SO wonderful on my scalp....  gotta look for the small blessings! Hugs,  Laura
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 03:49PM Kaidog wrote: Becky, I'm doing TCH too, then the Herceptin every 3rd week, just like you.  I just finished my second cycle.  Only four to go!  The first two flew by and I hope the others do, too.  How far along are you? I was getting my blood drawn yesterday for my Herceptin and the nurse told me that she'd never seen anything in her career like the impact of Herceptin on patients' lives.  I gather she was around when the clinical trial data started to come in, and suddenly everyone who was HER2 started getting Herceptin because it was such a stunning turnaround in outcomes.  She felt lucky to have been working in cancer treatment when such a revolution took place.  Pretty inspiring!  Susie, congratulations on making it through the weekend's er, fun...  How'd the golf tournament go? Laura
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2009 09:02AM Kaidog wrote: Laurie - I think four chemo rounds is PLENTY - heck, any chemo sucks.  When I hear about people who have to do chemo, surgery and rads, that makes me feel better about only doing surgery and chemo... BorneoMom - I will be thinking of you!  I had to move across town once with a sinus infection and thought that sucked.  You're moving around the world with chemotherapy.... WOW.  You amaze me. MamaQ - Have you tried Biotene?  I had luck with that, also with the salt/soda solution.  that felt good on the big fat canker sore I got my first week of chemo....  Joan - the important thing is that you're taking care of yourself NOW.  And remember, plenty of people who take terrible care of themselves don't get BC, while plenty of athletic people who DO take great care... end up with BC.  Don't blame yourself; it's more than whether or not you jogged regularly.   Susie - You look gorgeous! I did another Herceptin treatment yesterday... #5 of 18 weeks.   Slowly but surely we'll all get there, right?  Hugs, Laura
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2009 12:52PM Kaidog wrote: By the way, Carolyn, it's hot here in NM too. And I absolutely HATE having stuff on my head. So I am going out in public either completely bald or with a baseball hat for some sun protection, because it's simply too hot for even a scarf, much less a wig.  I get some startled looks, but I'm getting less self-conscious about it.   I keep reminding myself of the advantages: shorter showers, no money down the drain with expensive conditioners, my head stays cool...  And my coworkers tell me I have a nicely shaped skull!  No big bumps.  Laura
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2009 08:02AM Kaidog wrote: Laurie, I was with you in the dumps yesterday morning.  I kept thinking, FOURTEEN MORE WEEKS OF THIS? FOURTEEN???   I am doing the TCH regimen (three week cycles, TCH/H/H), and just had my second TCH infusion, so I'm four weeks into the eighteen weeks of chemo.  So far, I have to admit that my SEs aren't horrible - mostly nausea and tiredness, and some achiness  - but I get fatigued and depressed for a few days and I just hate feeling depressed.   I get all cosmic and weird - "What is the point of all of this?  People are starving and killing each other.  Global warming is destroying polar bears!"  Etc, etc, etc.   Like I said... cosmic.  However...  right now I am drinking my morning coffee and it's a lovely day and my dogs are happy and my husband got a good night's sleep and he's happy, too, so I feel better about the world.  I hope you have a better day, too!   I hear that Claritin helps with the bone pain if it's from Neupogen or Neulasta??? Laura
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2009 12:46PM Kaidog wrote: Hey MamaQ, I think that a really low WBC is pretty normal, depending on which chemo you're doing.  Mine usually plummets like that - as long as it comes back up after the nadir point, I think you're okay.  You probably want to avoid uncooked foods or stuff that might be contaminated, just in case - a bacterial infection can quickly spiral out of control.  I eat most stuff cooked, but I can't resist fresh fruit - I just soak it in iodine rise beforehand and so far, so good. Susie, it sounds like this guy really likes you.  Not surprising as your picture shows a very pretty woman and your posts are intelligent and funny and lively.  Your bed-baldness-worry is going to take care of itself along the way. Assuming he knows you're in treatment for cancer and wearing a wig, he is a) already prepared for you being bald and b) probably cares much less than you do about your hair loss.   I know that doesn't help with your own sense of discomfort, but maybe you can try to see yourself through his eyes.    I mean, the guy LIKES you.  Kick some a** on the golf course.  We're rooting for you!

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2009 05:56AM Kaidog wrote: I laughed when I read the header on this because I went through the SAME THING.  "Is there something they're not telling me???"  Turned out there wasn't - and here's how I found that out: I asked for copies of all the reports, imaging and pathology, for my own files.  Reading them was incredibly reassuring.   That was when I realized that the surgeon and radiologist both were concerned about the high density of my breast tissue, and wanted to be sure that it wasn't hiding something nasty as well.   In other words, they didn't know and were being conservative.  So get copies of your reports and try to relax.  Your brain can take you to all kinds of terrifying places when you're being diagnosed... I think it's part of the psychology of facing a major illness. You're stage one, so sounds good so far!  Hope all the news gets better and better (relatively speaking).

Posts.Content: May 9, 2009 08:29PM Kaidog wrote: PS73, this is a totally normal reaction.  You have a life threatening disease.   I saw your comment about getting a therapist... I found with my dad's brain cancer that getting counseling was a fabulous help for my emotional well-being.  I discovered a lot about myself in the process.  I'd even say that my dad's brain cancer was a gift, in a weird way - in some ways it prepared me for my own breast cancer diagnosis.  But without a great therapist (and she was AMAZING), I'd not have been able to find that silver lining. And yes, I've got a therapist now and she's amazing, too!
Posts.Title: When does it feel real? PS73 Makratz

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 11:38AM Kaidog wrote: Deb, don't panic yet!  The reason the woman on the phone told you no biopsy is because you really won't need a biopsy if it's a cyst. If the ultrasound shows that you have a cyst, it'll be crystal clear that it's a cyst, and you can breathe a sigh of relief!  Cysts show up very distinctively on an ultrasound because they're filled with liquid.  If it's a cyst, there's really nothing to biopsy - it would be like doing a biopsy on a blister.  You might want to have it aspirated if it gets big, but they usually go away on their own (I know because I had one). Biopsies are done on solid masses of tissue that appear suspicious.  If your radiologist sees something solid that's suspicious, believe me - they'll biopsy it.
Posts.Title: What is considered to be "early detection"? tobyholic lvtwoqlt

Posts.Content: May 21, 2009 07:40PM Kaidog wrote: I got my last drain out yesterday!!!  And I am staying very very very still so that I don't get a seroma.   This is one of those "things I wish I'd known before I went into surgery" - activity really does cause the fluids to flow into the wound area.  I WAS really active my second week and learned my lesson because I got a seroma in my right breast, had to have it drained...  and my left breast, where the drains were still in, was putting out about 50ml/day.  In my case, even spending too much time on the computer was irritating the area.   I had a hard time believing that I needed more recovery time because I've had minimal pain, no range of motion problems, not much fatigue, and feel very close to normal.  Anyway, I decided to try to minimize the fluid flow - I stayed as still as possible, tried not to put any weight on my sides (i.e., not rolling onto my side at night), and didn't use my arms, and that seems to have done the trick.  Within 3 days...  it had dried up, an no new seroma on the right! I promised DH and my surgeon that if the drain came out of my left side, I'd stay mellow through the weekend, then go back to work next week.   They took it out yesterday and I am back home.  Another few days in pajamas and watching movies... I'm bored, but it won't kill me. Hugs!  Laura

Didn't mean to imply otherwise...  No misinterpretation there. Once you've been in this position, you realize how intensely personal all of this is.  I'm glad we don't live in the era of my aunt (who survived 3 rounds of BC into her seventies): mostly male surgeons making decisions about double radical mastectomies without consulting the (female) patient.  These decisions are hard, but this is a better era to have breast cancer. Alaina, we're all rooting for you! Laura
Posts.Title: Making the Mastectomy Decision Kaidog mikita5

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 06:56PM Kaidog wrote: Hey Jenn,  I am 40 and I'm about to start my third TCH, but mine is Taxotere, Carboplatin and Herceptin, not Taxol-Cytoxan.  I'm ER/PR negative... your positive markers might mean you get something different; it think also depends on your staging.  I thought chemo would be a nightmare but it's not bad at all - I'm low energy and nauseated, like a hangover, for about 3 days out of every 3 weeks.  HER2 cancers are aggressive, so I figure it's worth the effort if it cuts my risk of a recurrence... I don't want to be dealing with metastatic cancer before I'm menopausal!   Can't wait for those hot flashes...  Ha Ha.
Posts.Title: anyone 40 Y.O. and having chemo? jennsdogs Lisa-Lisa

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 10:38AM Kaidog wrote: My takeaway is that for the vast majority of us, careful observation of the healthy breast for early detection is as effective mastectomy if the tissue is healthy.  Did I decide to do that?  Nope.  I took mine off because I've got very dense breast tissue and BC runs on my dad's side of the family.  I get BRCA counseling next week...  Anyway, I'd be eyeing my other breast obsessively. This study reassured me that, if nothing else, I fell into the category of women who were most likely to get a big absolute payoff, conditional on the very low probability that I'd have a second primary in the other breast.  But, yes, that's a  big assumption.  Mastectomy doesn't eliminate the risk of recurrence completely.  It just lowers it. What this all boils down to is that making decisions about cancer treatment eventually boils down to a very complicated crap shoot at some point.  Which raises an interesting problem... where we get the information to inform our decisions is a very challenging issue for most of us, and problematic as the medical community puts more of the treatment decisions into the hands of the patient.  I think that's a GOOD thing, very empowering; but it also brings its own stresses.  For example, most of us struggle to understand the math and logic that underlies risk and decision making.  Reading this discussion board, I think it's easy to assume that recurrence in the contralateral breast is common.  There are certainly many women who will read this thread and say, "I wish I'd gotten mine off the first time, because it came back!"  For the women who've been through a recurrence, the nightmare is very real, and the low risk doesn't matter any more - it's become 100% for them.  That's where statistics intersect with reality, and finding onself in the tail end of the distribution must be very scary place to be.  However, the women posting to this board represent only a tiny fraction of the total number of people who are diagnosed with breast cancer.  Studies show that most women diagnosed with BC won't have a recurrence in the other breast.  It would be interesting to know WHY that is the case, so that we could be peaceful in our decision to leave or remove the contralteral breast.  However, no one knows what makes one breast go postal while the other is perfectly happy to be normal; and that's the multi-billion dollar explanation for why cancer occurs.  Which, of course, we don't have, so we all muddle along as best as we can.    Anyway, blah-blah-blah...   it should be reassuring to many women that the decision to keep one's healthy breast is a fine decision - just keep up with that screening.  Laura
Posts.Title: Making the Mastectomy Decision Kaidog mikita5

Posts.Content: May 30, 2009 10:33AM Kaidog wrote: All I can say is this:  I don't regret my mastectomy decision at all!  I healed really fast & my new breasts are settling in beautifully.  Also, I don't have to do radiation, and if I do get a recurrence or second primary, it won't be able to hide behind lots of dense breast tissue because there simply ain't much left to hide in.   Not everyone has the kind of great post-surgical outcomes that I've had, so maybe I'm just really lucky, but so far, so good.  They're definitely different, but I am already very fond of my new saline friends. Now that all my dressings are off, I massage my skin every night with very nice almond oil to help desensitize the nerves, and that has helped immensely too.  It was very uncomfortable at first, but now it feels kind of nice and I'm actually kind of surprised at how much sensation I still have.  I recommend gentle skin massage to anyone getting a mastectomy - a PA told me to do this and it's really helped with the skin/muscle sensitivity. Alaina, just before my surgery I had exactly the opposite thought... that surgeons stand to make more money when they can "sell" a double MX.  Then I realized that my surgeons really did have my best interests at heart and forgot about it until I'd read your post above...   But it's easy to get cynical about all of this, particularly when you're considering tens (hundreds?) of thousands of dollars of treatment.  SIGH....
Posts.Title: Making the Mastectomy Decision Kaidog mikita5

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2009 09:15AM Kaidog wrote: Hey Tweety,  that's great news! I'm so glad you had a clear scan!  Isn't it a relief to see that at least some of your tissue is healthy and normal?   I had a double MX with reconstruction and, I must say, it looks great.  I think a single can be harder for the surgeon - matching can be tricky - but if you've got a good doctor you trust, that shouldn't be an issue.    Here's a question to ask your surgeon... how many unilateral reconstructions has s/he done?  If it's less than a couple of dozen, ask to be referred to someone who's done a lot of these since the matching can be tricky. You can also ask for photos of the very best AND the very worst outcomes, so you know what to expect.    Laura

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 11:40AM Kaidog wrote: Dawnbelle, I didn't think you were insinuating anything!  Sorry if I came across as snappish; wasn't my intention at all. It was more of a commiserating comment than anything else...  I wish we ALL had the cancer crystal ball.   That's what sucks... you have to make as informed a decision as you possibly can and then go for it.  Having a doctor you trust and love is a great blessing in all of this.  I'd ask the BS about mastectomy and get a second opinion.  Depending on the size of your breasts, where your expanders are, and how extensive the area of involvement, s/he might think that a mastectomy is an option.     Or maybe not...   Tweety, if you look through my previous posts, you can see what my chain of reasoning was.  I was going to do lumpectomy and rads until I did some research on recurrence and survival rates. If I'd been ER positive, had no history of breast cancer in my family, and my breasts were easier to mammogram, I'd have strongly considered the lumpectomy option. Laura

Posts.Title: Side Effects of TCH Chemo?? husband001 bluedasher

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2009 07:58AM Kaidog wrote: Surgery was not bad at all for me, and I had a double MX.  I was shocked at how little pain I had.  I imagine lumpectomy will be even easier; but as Anne writes, the node removal is somewhat more painful than the rest of the operation...  but very bearable, and goes away in a few weeks.  HOWEVER - if they're gonna knock you al the way out, DEFINITELY get going on the Metamucil ASAP.  Your body will thank you.   The constipation post-operation can be miserable, even with outpatient anaesthesia, and painkillers often make it worse.  Read the constipation thread on this board and you'll see what I mean.  It's an investment worth making!

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 11:55AM Kaidog wrote: I so know what you're feeling - I was worried about the impulsivity as well, but hey, they're BREASTS, not the frontal lobes of your brain!   Both my surgeons felt strongly that having a positive feeling about your treatment is an important aspect of your prognosis, and they've both been doing this for a long time.  Some women want to keep their breasts, others feel better with them off.   You need to do what's comfortable for you and not worry about what's "right."  I don't think worrying about the cosmetic results for your breasts is juvenile at all.  I was actually kind of surprised at how nonchalant I felt about losing my breasts - I've felt no grief over losing my breasts, just relief.  My hair, on the other hand... Hugs, L.
Posts.Title: Making the Mastectomy Decision Kaidog mikita5

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 09:41AM Kaidog wrote: Hey Dawnbelle, Beesie did a really nice job answering this.  I had a nipple sparing mastectomy on my left, which was clear of cancer; and an areola-sparing mastectomy on my right, where I had multifocal DCIS and over a dozen 2-4mm HER2+ small tumors (invasive areas).  Cosmetically, my left breast looks astoundingly like it did before the mastectomy.  My right one is a little more beat up, but that's where they did the SNB and such.  The reason I put in that last bit is because that's where a very small surgical surprise came in...  The biopsy showed that I had only microinvasions under a millimeter, but once they got it out, turned out there was a bit more more invasive cancer than expected, and it appears that I had two areas of DCIS.  Imaging is great, but as one woman put it to me, "They don't really know anything for sure until they've got it out of you and on a table in front of them." You've already had a lumpectomy, so it sounds like your cancer is out. If they did a lumpectomy, and got good margins, your cancer isn't dancing anywhere except for maybe on the slides in the pathologist's office.  Did they do a sentinel node biopsy?  Also, you're ER/PR positive - that's a GOOD thing, because tamoxifen is pretty powerful against those cancers.  I chose the double because a) there's BC in my family and b) I was ER negative...  I mean, like zero estrogen receptors.  Nil, nada, nix, naught, nothing... and c) I have super dense breast tissue and didn't want to be going for mammograms every six months and freaking out for the rest of my life.  Lastly, I loved my plastic surgeon and he promised me he'd do a great job, and he did!  So it worked out really well for me.  As for sensation - I should clarify that the sensation isn't pre-mastectomy normal.  I don't think I've got phantom sensation, but I can feel pressure on my skin and nipple.  It's definitely duller than it was before; and my nipples aren't responsive.  However, to be perfectly frank, my breasts were never a huge erogenous zone for me anyway and I just don't miss them.   Weird, huh?   If I lost sensation in the back of my neck or along my spine, I'd be extremely sad.  There's where my buttons are...  :) I think you probably need to talk to your surgeon and get your questions answered by her/him; and if you're still having issues, then get a second opinion about what to do. If two surgeons tell you that you've done enough for now, and you want to keep your breast, you can probably relax with that decision and know you've done everything you can.   Ultimately, we all have to make the decision that seems best at the time for us.  For a lot of women, that means saving the breast. The research indicates that, for most of us, prophylactic mastectomy perhaps offers more psychological benefit than survival benefit.   As long as your implants aren't obscuring breast tissue where other cancers might grow, of course.... and THAT IS WHERE YOU NEED TO TALK TO YOUR SURGEON, not to those of us who have experience but no medical degrees!  I wish I could offer you a map to the best outcome for YOU. Wouldn't it be great if we had that crystal ball??
Posts.Title: Making the Mastectomy Decision Kaidog mikita5

Posts.Content: May 18, 2009 08:57AM - edited May 18, 2009 11:24AM by Kaidog Beesie - yeah, this is a good one, isn't it?  Though I see where Alaina is coming from - and the one thing that this study doesn't address is the issue of psychological comfort and well-being. For some, that means a double MX. For others, it's keeping one breast (or doing a lumpectomy and saving as much breast tissue as possible). Alaina, I TOTALLY understand where you're coming from. If you want to PM me about the mastectomy experience, feel free - I made the same choice; and even if I weren't in the category that benefits, I'd be thinking of mastectomy too.  It's a very personal decision and your psychological well-being is perhaps the most important element of your treatment.  Also, it's not that bad...  I was amazed at how little pain I had.  Laura
Posts.Title: Making the Mastectomy Decision Kaidog mikita5

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2011 12:09AM Kaidog wrote: Yeah, I so remember that.   You will feel totally normal again, really.  Just don't expect to feel normal in less than a year!   It was 2 years from diagnosis before I felt like a normal human being again.  Let yourself crash after it's all over; treat yourself with kid gloves, and don't be angry or frustrated if you're not getting back into the swing of things as fast as you think you should.  The world won't end if your kitchen cabinets are dustier than you'd like.   One more thing: antidepressants help too!  Zoloft was a miracle drug for me.    Oh, and everyone says working out will help reverse the fatigue cycle, and no question it's a good thing, but damn, it was hard to do.  I could barely get out of bed in the morning.   What worked for me was the pedometer and gradually increasing my steps, then adding weight lifting - just a bit at a time! - and now I'm back to running.   So - take your time, Misswim!  You're young and pretty and you're going to be back to your normal self by 2013, and it won't feel like 2 years.  :) Hugs, Laura
Posts.Title: 29-ish Months Post-Diagnosis: You Will Get Through This! Kaidog MNSusan

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2011 05:47PM - edited Aug 26, 2011 06:08PM by Kaidog I am certainly not the only one who's arrived relatively unscathed at the other side.   Breast cancer is like a loop into an alternate reality, and then one day you realize you're out of the loop and back to normal.   It's all quite stressful but very survivable.   You are not doomed! Also, DE Miller is right - don't troll the Internet, and don't assume that the doomsday scenarios are crystal balls for your future.   The fact of the matter is that early stage breast cancer is darned close to being curable. Most women go through diagnosis and treatment once and they're done.  If you are reading this, and you've just been diagnosed, it is highly likely that you'll be in that "most women are fine" camp.  So, gear up to fight, get it over with, and then rest.  Rest.  Rest.  Before you know it, you've got enough hair for a ponytail and you can get through an entire week without needing a nap, and people will look surprised when they hear that you had cancer.  "You???  But you're so healthy!" Yup.
Posts.Title: 29-ish Months Post-Diagnosis: You Will Get Through This! Kaidog MNSusan

Posts.Content: Kaidog wrote: Hello survivors, I was diagnosed with Stage One, ER/PR-, HER2+, Stage One T1B BC on April 10, 2009 (Well, we didn't know it was T1B until a third pathology report much later, but that's a different story). My largest tumor was about 7mm.  I realize that my diagnosis wasn't particularly alarming, in retrospect.  But boy, do I remember the fear, terror, panic, nausea, crying that many of you are probably going through this weekend. If I could go back in time to talk to my terrified, sobbing self, here's what I'd say: It's all okay.  It all turned out fine.  Really.   The terror and panic are completely normal.  You have just had a life changing diagnosis and it really is terrifying.  However, you are not going to die.  Believe me, it won't be long before you'll be cursing at bad drivers again.    You're about to make a lot of really hard decisions.  Trust your judgment and don't let anyone second guess you.   You can really fill pushup bra with those gummy bear implants. You're going to gain 30 pounds, mostly during your post-treatment phase, when you eat gobs of carbohydrates to soothe yourself as you deal with the "What-the-hell-just-happened-to-me?" bewilderment of being at the end of treatment. As you recover your sense of balance and peace, regain energy, and get back into the swing of life, the weight will fall off.  Don't rush it (see "You'll be exhausted," below.)   You are about to discover that you rock bald like few other women can.   One word: sunscreen. You're going to lose friends.  You're going to make better friends.  You're going to discover that your male colleagues are among the most supportive, wonderful, understanding human beings you'll ever find in an office. You will find that all those little things that drove you nuts about your life partner are just that - little.  This human being is a rock and will save your sanity more than once.  One morning, you'll wake up to find your delicious morning coffee tastes like sewage.   That part sucks, but the coffee joy does return after chemo is over. You will be exhausted.  Let me repeat that: you will be exhausted.  In many ways, it's worse after all the treatment is over.  Your oncologist will chide you for rushing things, observing that your body and soul have just been in overdrive to fight a life-threatening diagnosis, so no wonder you're tired. So let yourself be tired.  Cut back on work. Don't take on so much.  It's only a year. Mysteriously, a month after you finish your last Herceptin treatment, and 15 months after diagnosis, you will wake up thinking about work.  Not cancer.  It will take you several hours to realize how significant this is.  Two years later, you'll run a half marathon in D-cup jogbra with your sister and feel great.  The vast majority of women with breast cancer diagnoses are just like this.  You're about to become one of them - someone who's been through it, recovered, and has reached a "new normal."    I know you're sick to your stomach, terrified, alarmed, panicked; you feel alone, you have a sense that you're facing a death sentence, you're horrified.  This is normal.  It's part of gearing up to fight.   You can do this, and there's a better life on the other side.  Breathe... and go kick some ass.  All my love,  Laura  Trying to love my chemo curls Dx 4/10/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/4 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 29-ish Months Post-Diagnosis: You Will Get Through This! Kaidog MNSusan

Posts.Title: 29-ish Months Post-Diagnosis: You Will Get Through This! Kaidog MNSusan

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2009 10:31AM - edited Jun 10, 2009 10:34AM by Kaidog Barbe - The weird itching was a surprise to me, too.  And it made me nuts!  I was also amazed at how little pain I had...   BUT how incredibly fatigued I was for about 6 days after the surgery.  By day 7, I started feeling perkier.  Okay, ladies, here's something to try!   My PA gave me a trick to help with the numbness and soreness:  skin massage.  As soon as your incisions are closing nicely, get some nice massage oill, preferably something unscented (almond is good!) and massage the skin that's tingling or numb.  It was very uncomfortable the first few times I did it, but my PA told me to stick with it.  She said that it helps the nerves settle down and can even encourage regeneration, because you're helping some "freaked out nerve endings" with some gentle stimulation.  I'm amazed at how much it helped with the tingly numb feeling and that sunburn skin feeling.  It also helped me feel more comfortable with my new boobs!   Laura
Posts.Title: Things that surprised me after mastectomy Lursa5 Ariom

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2011 11:54PM - edited Aug 22, 2011 12:00AM by Kaidog Hey Mags, I so remember the double mastectomy day.  You are going to be fine, fine, fine.  The surgery isn't so bad because it doesn't involve bone (though the lymph area will be sore for a while).  My two suggestions:
Posts.Title: 29-ish Months Post-Diagnosis: You Will Get Through This! Kaidog MNSusan

Posts.Content: Kaidog wrote: Hey all, I had a double MX on April 30th.  I had 3 drains put in, but I got 2 of them out about 6 days after my surgery.  However, I have one Jackson Pratt drain left that's been in for 16 days.  It's still filling about 40-50ml/24 hours.  My surgeon said that 2-3 weeks isn't unusual for drains to stay in.  It actually doesn't bother me that much, and I don't want to get a seroma, so I won't rush it...  but  I'm wondering if there's anything I can do to minimize the drainage?  Or is it just going to run its course?    Anyone else had drains that hung around for a while? Thanks!  Laura   Trying to love my chemo curls Dx 4/10/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/4 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Drains Kaidog tired

Posts.Content: Kaidog wrote: http://www.prohealthcare.org/wellness/health-news/mental-health/psychological-counseling-boosts-breast-cancer-outcomes.aspx Many of you have probably already seen this...  It's something I knew intuitively, but it's kind of cool to see at least an early study that emphasizes the importance of getting emotional support for breast cancer stress.   Healing light to all, Laura   Trying to love my chemo curls Dx 4/10/2009, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/4 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Mind over Matter! Kaidog Kaidog

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2009 02:01PM Kaidog wrote: They use titanium because it's extremely unusual for the human body to react to it - my doctor described it as "invisible" to the immune systme.  Depending on where they leave it, you probably won't even realize it's there.  The stereotactic biopsy was painless for me.  I hope yours is a) easy and b) benign.  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: stereotactic biopsy question beacon800 beacon800
